policy.name: EU AI Act
policy.description: World's first comprehensive legal framework for AI, establishing a risk-based classification system with tiered obligations. Bans unacceptable-risk AI (social scoring, real-time biometric surveillance), imposes strict requirements on high-risk systems (hiring, credit, law enforcement), and mandates transparency for general-purpose AI models.
key_provisions: Risk-based classification: unacceptable, high, limited, and minimal risk tiers
Mandatory conformity assessments and CE marking for high-risk AI systems
Transparency obligations for general-purpose AI models including frontier models
Creation of the European AI Office to oversee implementation
Fines up to 35M EUR or 7% of global turnover for violations
Regulatory sandboxes for SMEs and startups in each member state

qualitative_insights: Phased enforcement (banned practices first, then high-risk) gave industry time to adapt, but created confusion about which phase applies to which system
SME exemptions and regulatory sandboxes were critical for maintaining innovation; countries without active sandboxes saw 20% more startup relocations
The risk classification approach proved transferable to non-EU countries adopting similar frameworks, making it a de facto global standard

sources: European Commission AI Act Impact Assessment (2024)
OECD AI Policy Observatory - EU AI Act Tracker
Centre for Data Innovation: Cost of AI Act Compliance (2024)

policy.name: Artificial Intelligence and Data Act (AIDA)
policy.description: Part of Bill C-27, AIDA establishes a regulatory framework for AI systems in Canada. It focuses on high-impact AI systems, requires impact assessments, mandates transparency, and creates a new AI and Data Commissioner role. Builds on Canada's existing leadership in AI research through the Pan-Canadian AI Strategy.
key_provisions: High-impact AI system classification with mandatory impact assessments
Transparency requirements including plain-language explanations of AI decisions
Prohibition of AI systems that cause serious harm to individuals
Creation of the AI and Data Commissioner for enforcement
Mandatory reporting of material harm caused by AI systems
Interoperability with provincial privacy legislation (PIPEDA alignment)

qualitative_insights: Bundling AI regulation with broader digital privacy reform (Bill C-27) slowed the legislative process but produced a more coherent legal framework
Canada's existing AI research ecosystem (Montreal, Toronto, Edmonton hubs) cushioned the regulatory impact on innovation compared to countries without established AI sectors
The high-impact system classification was initially too vague, requiring extensive guidance documents that delayed practical compliance by 6+ months

sources: Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada - AIDA Overview
Canadian AI Institute: AIDA Compliance Landscape Report (2024)
OECD Digital Economy Outlook: Canada Chapter (2024)

policy.name: Model AI Governance Framework (2nd Edition) and AI Verify
policy.description: Singapore's voluntary governance framework provides detailed guidance for deploying AI responsibly. Combined with AI Verify, an open-source AI governance testing toolkit, it offers a practical, industry-friendly approach. Emphasizes self-assessment, transparency, and international interoperability without binding legal mandates.
key_provisions: Voluntary adoption with strong government encouragement and industry incentives
AI Verify testing toolkit for self-assessment against governance principles
Four guiding principles: transparency, fairness, explainability, human-centricity
Sector-specific guidance for finance, healthcare, and government services
International partnerships for mutual recognition of AI governance standards
AI governance body (IMDA) provides advisory support to adopting organizations

qualitative_insights: Voluntary approach achieved faster adoption among large enterprises but left a long tail of non-participating SMEs; government procurement preferences helped bridge this gap
AI Verify toolkit lowered compliance costs significantly by providing free, standardized testing rather than requiring each company to build its own audit process
Singapore's small size enabled rapid iteration on the framework; larger or federal countries would face coordination challenges replicating this model

sources: IMDA: AI Governance Framework Adoption Report (2024)
AI Verify Foundation: First Year Impact Assessment
World Economic Forum: Singapore AI Governance Case Study (2024)

policy.name: Rwanda National AI Policy
policy.description: Rwanda's national AI strategy positions the country as a continental leader in responsible AI adoption. Focuses on using AI to accelerate development goals in agriculture, healthcare, and financial inclusion. Prioritizes capacity building, data infrastructure, and public-private partnerships over heavy regulation.
key_provisions: AI Centre of Excellence for research, training, and policy advisory
Priority sectors: agriculture, healthcare, financial inclusion, and smart cities
Public-private partnership framework for AI deployment in government services
Data governance principles aligned with the African Union Data Policy Framework
Capacity building targets: 5000 AI-skilled workers by 2027
Ethical AI guidelines with emphasis on inclusive design and local language support

qualitative_insights: Rwanda's strong centralized governance enabled rapid policy adoption, but limited private sector AI capacity meant implementation depended heavily on international partnerships
Focusing on development-oriented AI (agriculture yield prediction, health diagnostics) generated visible public value quickly and built political support for further investment
Low compliance costs reflect the strategy's emphasis on enablement over regulation, making it highly relevant for countries at similar development stages

sources: Rwanda Ministry of ICT and Innovation: National AI Policy Document (2023)
Smart Africa: Rwanda AI Readiness Assessment (2024)
African Union: Continental AI Strategy Progress Report (2024)

policy.name: Brazilian AI Regulation Framework (PL 2338/2023)
policy.description: Brazil's comprehensive AI regulation draws inspiration from the EU AI Act but adapts it to Brazilian legal traditions and development priorities. Establishes a risk-based system, creates a new regulatory authority, and includes strong provisions for algorithmic impact assessments and affected persons' rights, reflecting Brazil's experience with LGPD (data protection law).
key_provisions: Risk-based classification system inspired by but distinct from the EU AI Act
Mandatory algorithmic impact assessments for high-risk AI systems
Rights of affected persons: explanation, contestation, and human review
National AI authority with enforcement and guidance mandates
Special provisions for public sector AI use in social benefits and justice
Innovation-friendly clauses: regulatory sandboxes and SME support programs

qualitative_insights: Brazil's existing experience implementing LGPD (data protection) provided institutional knowledge and regulatory infrastructure that accelerated AI regulation readiness
Strong civil society engagement during drafting ensured robust affected persons' rights, but industry groups warned that contestation rights could create legal uncertainty
The public sector provisions addressing algorithmic bias in social benefit allocation resonated with developing countries facing similar challenges

sources: Brazilian National Congress: PL 2338/2023 Legislative Record
Data Privacy Brasil: AI Regulation Impact Analysis (2024)
Inter-American Development Bank: AI Policy in Latin America (2024)

policy.name: UK Pro-Innovation AI Regulation Framework
policy.description: The UK's principles-based, sector-led approach delegates AI regulation to existing regulators (FCA, Ofcom, CMA, etc.) rather than creating new AI-specific legislation. Emphasizes flexibility, proportionality, and maintaining the UK's competitiveness post-Brexit. Central government provides cross-cutting principles while regulators adapt them to their domains.
key_provisions: Five cross-cutting principles: safety, transparency, fairness, accountability, contestability
Sector regulators implement principles within their existing mandates
No new standalone AI legislation; relies on existing regulatory powers
AI Safety Institute for frontier model evaluation and research
Regulatory sandbox programs across financial services, health, and telecoms
Central coordination function to prevent gaps and overlaps between regulators

qualitative_insights: Distributing responsibility across existing regulators enabled faster initial response but created coordination challenges; the financial sector moved 6 months ahead of healthcare
The absence of binding legislation was attractive to AI companies (several chose London over EU cities) but faced criticism from civil society for lacking enforcement teeth
The AI Safety Institute's technical evaluation work on frontier models provided a globally recognized contribution that elevated the UK's influence beyond its regulatory approach

sources: UK Department for Science, Innovation and Technology: AI Regulation White Paper (2024)
Alan Turing Institute: UK AI Governance Tracker (2024)
Ada Lovelace Institute: Regulating AI in the UK Report (2024)

policy.name: Tunisia National AI Strategy
policy.description: Tunisia's national AI strategy positions the country as a North African AI hub, leveraging its strong francophone technical education system and proximity to European markets. Focuses on building local AI capacity, supporting Arabic/French NLP development, and applying AI to key economic sectors including agriculture, tourism, and public administration.
key_provisions: National AI research center with university partnerships across Tunis, Sfax, and Sousse
Priority sectors: agriculture modernization, tourism optimization, e-government services
Bilingual (Arabic/French) AI development incentives and NLP research funding
Data governance framework aligned with Tunisia's 2004 data protection law (updated)
AI skills development program targeting 3000 specialists by 2026
International cooperation framework prioritizing EU and African Union partnerships

qualitative_insights: Tunisia's francophone legal tradition and bilingual education system make it the most directly comparable case for Morocco; lessons learned transfer with minimal adaptation
Limited government budget meant heavy reliance on international donor funding (EU, GIZ, World Bank), which introduced external priorities into the strategy's implementation
The focus on Arabic/French NLP created a genuine competitive advantage in a niche underserved by global tech companies, attracting nearshoring opportunities from European firms

sources: Tunisia Ministry of Communication Technologies: National AI Strategy Document (2023)
UNESCO: AI Readiness Assessment - Tunisia (2023)
African Development Bank: Digital Transformation in North Africa (2024)

policy.name: AI Basic Act (AI Gibonbeop)
policy.description: South Korea's comprehensive AI legislation balances strong industrial policy with human rights protections. Reflects the country's position as a major AI developer (Samsung, LG, Naver, Kakao) while addressing algorithmic discrimination concerns. Includes significant public investment commitments and a unique approach to high-impact AI designation that considers both risk and economic significance.
key_provisions: High-impact AI designation system combining risk assessment and economic impact criteria
Mandatory transparency reports for high-impact AI including training data documentation
National AI Committee chaired by the President for cross-ministerial coordination
Significant public R&D investment commitment: 1.5 trillion KRW annually for AI
AI impact assessments required for public sector deployment
Workforce transition support programs for AI-displaced workers

outcomes.measurement_period: 2024-Q1 to 2025-Q3 (implementation phase with rapid corporate adoption)
qualitative_insights: Combining regulation with massive public R&D investment sent a clear signal that the government was serious about both AI leadership and AI safety, improving industry buy-in
High compliance rates reflect South Korea's strong corporate governance culture and the large chaebol companies' ability to absorb compliance costs that would burden smaller firms
The workforce transition provisions were politically essential for building public support but proved difficult to implement effectively due to the speed of AI adoption outpacing retraining programs

sources: Korea Legislation Research Institute: AI Basic Act Analysis (2024)
KISDI (Korea Information Society Development Institute): AI Policy Impact Report (2024)
OECD AI Policy Observatory: South Korea Country Profile (2024)
